cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.

Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.

STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1904.

div.head: BRITISH SUBJECTS IN EGYPT.
div.p: We often hear of English judges complaining of the careless drafting of some new Act of Parliament, but we confess we have seldom come across a more extraordinary sample of what the legal advisers to the Government can be guilty of than the projected law of nationality, which was drawn up a few years ago in order to settle the vexed question of the status of all British subjects resident in foreign countries. The provisions of the proposed law were discusse and framed by a Commission, which consis d of the Law Officers of the Crown and he Under Secretaries of State, assisted by the most competent Counsel, and were drawn up so as expressly to include the status of British subjects domiciled in the Turkish dominions and in Egypt. It would naturally be thought that such a law would be so framed as to preserve the rights of Britishers, whose privileges had been guarded by the Capitulations for four centuries past, and that, considering the great commercial interests which England has in the Near East, special attention would have been paid to keeping intact he nationality of those British communities who are scattered throughout the Levant. Ever since the Capitulations were first instituted, four hundred years ago, the right of British subjects to transmit their nationality to their children, under certain recognised conditions, has been preserved by unbroken usage. This usage had been upheld in many legal decisions, for it was against all the traditions of our prestige that the offspring of British subjects should be degrad ed to the rank of rayahs against their will and by the mere operation of law. But according to the clauses of the proposed law British subjects of the third generation, born in the Ottoman Empire and in Egypt, would cease to be recognised as such, no matter whether they were of the most unsullied English or Scotch descent. The injustice of this is obvious. While rich rayah aliens could attain the rank of British subjects by spending a portion of their summer holidays in England and taking a house there, the children of poor Englishmen resi dent in the Lovant, who were unable to avail themselves of such means, would become Turkish subjects and thus, deprived of their pre cious birth-right, would insensibly sink to the level of the decayed races with whom they were brought daily into contact. Cast off by their fatherland, deprived of their distinctive nationality, they would no longer be able to maintain that insular exclusiveness which is the secret of the success of the English in. maintaining unimpaired the strength of their race amid the surroundings of the East. Fortunately, some public-spirited members of the British colony at Constantinople went to considerable troub and expense in explaining the injustice of th proposed law to the home r.authorities, wo-but only after three appeals-decided to recognise the full British status of Brith subjects of whatever generation born Turkey or Egypt. In another column we publish a communication from these gentlemen, and we sincerely hope that their appeal will meet with immediate response from Egypt, where many members of the British colony would have been seriously affected as regards the status of their families, if the grievance had not been taken up and pushed so strenuously. They are out of pocket to the extent of £300. It is a very small amount for an achievement of such importance, and we hope many subscriptions will be forthcoming from this country. 0 B

div.head: ABYSSINIA AS A MARKET.
div.p: The early patch of a German commercial mission to Assinia should act as a warning to English manufacturers and merchants to "wake up." All travellers in that country are prac- tically agreed is to its presenting many pro- mising openis for European trade. The Negus, too, is more than willing to substitute commerce for fighting as the chief national industry, provided that "pacific penetration' for political purposes is not attempted. While most careful to hold the balance equally be- tween outside nationalities desirous of selling to or buying from his subjects, the Emperor naturally feels sympathetically drawn to those neighbours of his who smashed his most dan- gerous foe, the Mahdi. Apart from that res- cue of Abyssinia from a standing peril, it is conterminous with the Sudan for hundreds of miles, and the seems every likelihood of a considerable volume of frontier trade gra dually being built up. On the Eastern side, France has got the lead through the construc tion of a railway from Djibouti to Harrar, but a British line from the coast will, before very long, come into rivalry. There has been some talk, also, about a branch from the Khartoum terminus of the Egypt-Sudan railway to Western g Abyssinia; the engineering difficulties are said of to be slight. ut dealing with the situation as mit now presens itself no time should be lost by of our producer and distributors in sending in- ntelligent agents to ascertain what are the real 1 wants of the country, and this is equally in important the prices the population would 1s be able to pay for British supplies.

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
MORE SHIPS DESTROYED. TORPEDO ATTACKS. "SEVASTOPOL" DAMAGED

div.p: Officials during the bombardment on the 13th inst., the Japanese fired a torpedo depot at Tiger's Tail. Three ships were destroyed, and another, which was lying in the vicinity, was sunk.

Admiral Togo reports that the torpedo-boats a made five attacks on the "Sevastopol " during Monday and Tuesday night. The results are not yet ascertained. The Japanese were met by a fierce fire. One torpedo boat was disabled e and bad to be towed back. She was hit three times, and had three casualties.
At Port Arthur, three Russian torpedo-boats have been destroyed, four Japanese torpedo- boats injured, and the battleship "Sevastopol "s seriously damaged.
The "Sevastopol" is afloat but damaged.

The Japanese torpedo-boats renewed the attack on the "Sevastopol" and military transports yesterday morning in the midst of a severe snowstorm and heavy seas, which caused t them to lose touch with each other. A torpedo- boat is missing. The decks of the torpedo-boats were coated with ice. The "Sevastopol" was protected by boom logs covered with iron, in addition to torpedo-nets, but the Japanese succeeded in reaching and damaging her.

div.head: THE DUKE OF CONNAUGHT
HH'S VISIT TO EGYPT.
div.p: The Duke of Connaught, accompanied by the Duchess, will leave early in January on board the cruiser "Essex," in order to inspect the forces and fortresses in the Mediterranean and Egypt.

div.head: RUSSIAN LIBERAL MOVEMENT.
BECOMING MORE MANIFEST.
div.p: The growth of the liberal movement in Russia is more manifest every day. The news- papers are, in an outspoken manner, advocating the adoption of the far-reaching reforms which the students and educated classes are emphatically demanding at their meetings.

div.head: HUNGARIAN DIET.
RENEWED INDESCRIBABLE UPROAR.
div.p: A renewed indescribable uproar took place. in the Diet to-day. The Premier was unable to obtain a hearing. He stood with folded arms for 30 minutes, while the infuriated members of the Opposition howled, demanding him to resign. Finally the sitting broke up in disorder.

div.head: M. SYVETON'S SUICIDE.
A DOMESTIC SCANDAL.
div.p: It transpires M. Syveton's suicide was intended to cover a most painful domestic scandal in which M. Syveton and his step- daughter were mainly concerned.

div.head: SWISS CONFEDERATION.
ELECTION OF PRESIDENT.
div.p: M. Ruchet has been elected President of the Swiss Confederation.

div.head: HELLENIC CHAMBER.
ELECTION OF PRESIDENT.
div.p: M. Bouphides has been elected President of the Chamber of Deputies.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD,
div.p: ALEXANDRIA.
8s. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED.
H.H.S. "Aida" will leave Suez for the Red Sea about the 30th inst.
THE BRINDISI MAIL will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.30 p.m. on Sunday.
MANY HAPPY RETURNS of the day to H.H. Prince Abdul Mouneim, the young Heir Appa- rent to the Khediviate.
QUARANTINE. A telegram from Constan- tinople states that arrivals from Suez are now subject to a medical examination.
SUDAN INSPECTION.-It is believed Sir Wm. Garstin will leave for the Sudan early next month on a tour of inspection.
ASSIZE COURTS.We understand the new law relative to Assize Courts will probably be promulgated early in January.
THE IMPERIAL GERMAN CONSULATE at Alex- andria has re-appointed the Egyptian Gazette as the official journal of the consulate for 1905.

SHEPHEARD'S. The small dance last night at Shepheard's Hotel was a great success from every point of view. Considering how early it still is, the attendance made one imagine that we were in the vortex of the season.

H. M. S. Sutlej," first-class armoured cruiser (Capt. W. L. Grant), arrived at Port Said yesterday, outward bound for the China station, where she will relieve H.M.S. "Levia than." The vessels will meet at Colombo.

SUEZ CANAL. On the 12th inst. 10 vessels passed through the Suez Canal, 8 of which were British, 1 Dutch, 1 Italian. The receipts for the day amounted to irs. 273,488.89. For the period from 1st to 13th inst. the total re- ceipts were frs. 4,608,535.66.

SUDAN POSTAL DEVELOPMENT.- A A post and telegraph office has been opened at Geteina, in the Sudan. The post office is open for ordinary and registered correspondence, ordinary par cels, inland ordinary and telegraphic money orders, and foreign ordinary money orders.

THE KOM OMBO AFFAIR. Judge Falqui, of the Italian Consular Court at Cairo, and M. Alerio, Italian Vice Consul, have gone to Upper Egypt to enquire into the case of M. Puccinelli, an employé of the Kom Ombo Syndicate, who was attacked by a tribe of Bedouins recently.

VICTORIA COLLEGE. On January 2, 1905, there will be opened a preparatory school for little boys between the ages of six and eight. The fee, which includes the midday meal, has been fixed at L.E.2 per month. The boys will be taught in a separate building erected for the purpose in the enclosed playground of Victoria College.

STILL THEY COME-The great continental financial establishments are flocking to Egypt. Only the other day the Banco di Roma and the National Bank of Greece decided to open branches at Alexandria and Cairo, and now the Comptoir National d'Escompte of Paris has announced its intention of opening a branch here.

MOTORS . TRAMS.--It is expected that the board of directors of the Alexandria Tramway Company and Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company will find some modus vivendi whereby cut-throat competition with the new motor omnibus company will be avoided. Matters are progressing so fast that we shall soon see motor omnibuses for the conveyance of the public on the streets of Alexandria.

VERB. SAP. For the last two or three days, a native tinsmith has been going the rounds of several houses in Alexandria and has ob- tained admission on the pretence that he had e been sent by the landlord to carry out certam repairs to the sanitary appliances of the house. Householders would do well to be on their guard, as the man in question is a common thief, and has in this manner succeeded in pur- .loining various articles from the houses he has honored with a visit.

FRENCH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. -- The November Bulletin of the French Chamber of Commerce of Alexandria contains an im- portant article on the necessity for a new line of navigation between Egypt and France which we have summarised in another column. sThere are also articles dealing with French c trade, a commercial review, a useful synopsis - of the Budget for 1905, statistics of general im- ports, of the imports from France into Egypt, the statistics of the general exports from Egypt during September, of Egyptian exports to France, etc., etc. During last month the Chamber received 23 new members. We hope the British Chamber of Commerce is adding to its roll of members at the same rate.

DANTE ALIGHIERI SOCIETY.-The recent -) attack on Italians by Germans at Innsbruck has aroused considerable emotion amongst the members of the Italian colony at Alexandria. With a view to contributing towards the fund raised for the victims of this outrage, the Dante Alighieri Society and the Italian Mutual Benefit Association of Alexandria will, with the assistance of the members of the local amateur dramatic club, "Ernesto Rossi," give a performance at the Abbas Helmy Theatre at Alexandria on Sunday evening next of Gerolamo Rovelta's drama Romanticismo. Subscriptions will be received by Cav, Luigi Alfeo Panighini, Ronci, Sisters-street, Cav. Attarin-street, and Messrs. Bellantuono and DB Folcia, Tewfik Pasha-street,
Admiral Rodjestvensky arrived at Angra Pequena on the 11th inst. It is reported that he is coaling from colliers.
Admiral Foelkersalm's fleet is still at Djibouti, awaiting that of Admiral Botrovosky.
Admiral Felkersahm's squadron quitted Djibouti waters yesterday evening.
Admiral Togo's fleet is going to be thoroughly overhauled and refitted, in order to be in readiness to meet the Baltic Fleet.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayers to- day at Montazah Mosque.
This evening, his Highness will celebrate the birthday fête of Prince Mohamed Bey Abdul Moneim at Montazah Palace.
His Highness and the Khedivial family will return to Koubbeh to-morrow.
His Highness has conferred the rank of Mirmiran on Mohamed Bey Mohsen.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS.
div.p: Sir Horace Pinching's reply to the Cairo pharmacists was read at a meeting of the committee on Wednesday Wednesday night. As the letter was written in English, and as the majority of the committee are not well versed in the language, French translations are being prepared which will be given to each member.

As far as we can gather, the great majority of the Cairo pharmacists still remain strongly opposed to the second article of the new Regulations, to which we have already re- ferred. They argue that, while the prohibi- tion against any proprietor of a pharmacy interfering in any way with the conduct of the shop is excellent in theory, it would be almost impossible in practice to ensure its being obeyed.

div.head: KERMA RAILWAY LINE.
div.p: The Kerma line will be closed for both Government and public traffic after the 31st inst. As the removal of the permanent way will be immediately proceeded with, the run- ning of any trains for stores, etc., however urgent, will be a matter of impossibility.

div.head: ATTEMPTED TRAIN DERAILMENT.
div.p: At 3.30 a.m. on the morning of the 8th inst., some suspicious characters from the village of El-Atamnah, Tahta district, went to the railway line between Meshta and Tahta stations and proceeded to lay across the rails some huge stones and large sleepers, with the object of wrecking the up "train de luxe." Fortunately, the ghafirs in charge of the rail- way at this spot during the night caught sight of them before they had laid a sufficient quantity of stones and wood to do very much eharm. Unable to clear the line before the fast approaching train came along, the ghathirs rushed after the perpetrators, who took to their heels, and fired on them. They succeeded in outrunning one of the men, who, seemingly $through his advanced age, could not keep up with his two companions. He was arrested and found to be Ahmed Abdel-Al, the other two being his sons. The engine-driver, when passing this place, felt a heavy jolt and the train was brought to a standstill, much to the alarm of the passengers. The driver found that the "forerunner" was damaged but he stook the train as far as Sohag, where the engine was changed.

News of the occurrence was wired to the Le Ministry of the Interior, who sent orders to the er Moudir (who was on leave) to return at once. The Substitute of Parquet, together with the Mamour of Tahta, proceeded to the spot and ce held an enquiry. From this it was found that 1. the criminals arrested planned the outrage in order to bring their omdeh into disgrace. They supposed that there would be many victims near their village, and that this might cause to lose his post.
A similar outrage occurred at the same spot some four years ago, and the then omdeh, e failing to discover the criminals, was dismissed.

I may also mention that four months ago, some vagabonds of the neighbouring town of Bangha plotted in a similar way against their omdeh. They went at night to the railway, sawed off the k telegraph poles, and fired at the engine-driver of the express train that was passing at the time. In consequence of this the Mamour appointed seventeen ghaffirs to watch over the railway lines near these two towns. Were it not the watchful eyes of the ghaffirs, the train luxe would have been in great danger being derailed.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL.
div.p: Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. nd Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English buarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.

div.head: BRITISH AGENCY RECEPTION.
A BRILLIANT FUNCTION.
div.p: The Countess of Cromer was "at home" at the British Agency on Wednesday evening. Upwards of four hundred people were said to be present, including the leading members of the foreign colonies, the officers of the Army of Occupation and of the Egyptian Army, etc. etc., and the function was most stately and brilliant. Lord and Lady Cromer received their guests at the entrance to the ball-room, where dancing proceeded with great animation until after midnight. The Ladies' Orchestra provided the music and their performance contributed much to the enjoyment of the 1 evening. Refreshments were served in the dining-room and were, as usual, perfection.

The season is still young, and everybody was looking fresh and well. We noticed a great number of smart gowns; the abolition of long trains was felt and appreciated in the ball-room, and had, moreover, an appre- ciable efect upon upon the free space of the reception-rooms in general. White struck the keynote of fashion, and among those who wore it was Lady Cromer, in a pearl shade of rich satin, relieved by flounces of white net, and emerald and diamond jewels. Lady Beatrice Thynne wore a white lace robe; Mrs. George Royle was in white and gold Mrs. Satow, too, wore white satin. Lady Palmer was attired most becomingly in a dress of subdued salmon-pink of two shades, e ornamented with an embroidery of roses. y Miss Slade wore a striking frock of lustrous, rose-pink silk, the skirt hanging in full folds and 11the bodice made in the new "Directoire" style, with a high, pointed waist-band. Madame of Fabricius looked exceedingly well in a lovely dress of pale, soft mauve, trimmed with deep flounces of exquisite lace. The Hon. Mrs. Davey struck a different note in a dainty 'Pompadour gown, in vanishing shades of blue and gold with a white sheen over it; with this she wore a wreath of silver leaves. eLady Rogers also wore a distinctive gown in the nouvel art style, of soft, oyster-grey satin dwith straps of bright peacock-blue velvet, and paste clasps in the form of the star and cres- cent. Miss Purley affected the 'Early Victo- rian' mode with great success. Mrs. Brunyate ywas in blue and black. Miss Coles looked pretty in girlish white muslin.

Among others present we noticed H. E. Mirza Ali Askhar Khan, Persian Agent and Consul General, Mr. and Mrs. A. D. Alban, Mr. of Sheldon Amos, M., Mme. and Mlle. Barois, Mr. and Mrs. Brunyate, Mme. and Mlle. Bretsch- neider, Mr. and Mrs. McGeough Bond, Mrs. Birdwood, the Very Rev. Dean and Mrs. But- cher, Mr. Hugh Blomfield, Mr. and Mrs. Clif- ton, Mr. and Mrs. Coghlan, H.E. Coles Pasha, Mrs. and the Misses Coles, Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Carey, Miss Caillard, Mr. and Mrs. st Cotterill, Hon. and Mrs. Davey, M. and Mme. y Dilbéroglue, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Elliot, Sir William Garstin, M. and Mme. Pierre Girard, er Mr. Graves, Dr. and Mrs. Goodman, Dr. and Mrs. Hayward, Mr. and Mrs. Hooker, Mr. Humphreys, Mr. Halton, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Allan Joseph, Dr. and Mrs. Keatinge, Mr. and Mrs. Langley, Mr. and Mrs. Littlewood, Capt. h Lyons, Mr. Morgan, Mrs. Malcolm McIlwraith, e Dr. Murison, M., Mme. and Mlles. von Mohl, at Purvis Bey, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer, M.Pe- alizaeus, Mr. and Mrs. Rowlatt, Sir John and s Lady Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. George Royle, Dr. e and Mrs. Elliott-Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Satow, "Mr. and Mrs. Sharman, Mr. Bowden Smith, 1- Mr. and Mrs. Sheppard, Major Spong, Mr. and at Mrs. Trevithick, Lewa Thurneyssen Pasha, at Judge and Mrs. Tuck, M. and Mme. div.head: ALEXANDRIA-DUNKIRK.
PROPOSED STEAMSHIP SERVICE.
div.p: In referring to the rapid extension of Egyptian trade, both export and import, the Bulletin of the French Chamber of Commerce points out that three powerful factors combine in this evolution, i.e., (1) the considerable in-. crease in the population; (2) the extension of fcultivation; (3) the high price reached by cotton during recent years. The last two 1 items, it is said, bring in a net profit of 125 million francs.

The imports into Egypt, which in 1895 amounted to L.E. 8,389,933, were in 1903 L.E. 16,753,190, while the exports in the same period increased from L.E. 12,816,597 to L.E. 19,539,524. These figures are eloquent, but the returns for 1904 will be still more striking, as at the end of October the increase over the same date in 1903 was about 60,000,000 afrancs in imports and 53,000,000 in exports.

The Chamber is of course mainly interested in the share which France has taken in this increase of trade, and finds that country has made progress on a par with Egypt. The 3 imports from France rose from L.E. 934,165 in 1895 to L.E. 1,647,506 in 1903, while the exports to that country increased in value from L.E. 1,035,627 to L.E. 1,685,316. In Vview of these figures the Chamber is led to enquire if the service of navigation between the two countries keeps pace with the in- crease in trade, and is reluctantly bound ato admit that this is not so. For example, the tonnage of French steamships calling at Alexandria in the period under review only 8 increased from 286,000 to 305,000, while their number decreased from 137 to 115.

Thus, while French trade has almost doubled, French maritime lines are where they were in V1895. On the other hand, England has in Pcreased her tonnage by 297,590, Germany by 82,715, and Italy by 81,707, which three countries have no doubt benefited to a great extent by the increase in trade with France.

The Chamber suggests the establishment of a service between Dunkirk and Alexandria, the ships to call at St. Nazaire, Bordeaux, E 1 Algiers, and Tunis on the way. This proposed ditinerary has already been under consideration by several steamship owners, but the financial risk has always proved the principal obstacle eto its establishment. This risk, judging by the figures given, would seem to have disappeared, and, in the opinion of the Chamber, no- thing stands in the way of the project being realised.

The Bulletin then goes on to give particulars of the principal imports from the various ports of France and holds out a glowing prospect 5. for the company with the enterprise necessary to start the proposed steamship line. A fmonthly service would, it maintains, be sufficient for a commencement, and this might 5. be extended as the need arose.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending yesterday, 33 deaths d from bovine typhus were reported throughout r.Egypt, as against 23 in the previous week. s During the corresponding week last ar (December 1 to 13) 1,482 deaths were reported.
Since the beginning of the epidemic, the 1, total number of deaths amounts to 146 649. During the last week one new locality was a declared infected, namely, Dametnou r. Mehallet el Kobra district.
416 serum inoculations were made during ,the week.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending yesterday, 3 cases of bubonic plague occurred, all of a pnemonic character and all ending fatally. Of these cases, one occurred in the Toukh district, one at Port Said, and another at Suez.

div.head: P. W. D. CONTRACTS.
div.p: Mustapha Eff. El-Gammal has obtained the contract for the supply of 1,400 tons of Cardiff coal and 800 tons Newcastle for the Kssassin pumps, at the price of L.E. 1.410 per ton for the former and L.E. 1.310 for the latter.
The contract for the construction of a sudd in the Nile at Mehallet el-Amir has been awarded to M. F. Baldi, at the price of L.E. 9,600.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor" sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon and is due here about the 29th inst. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Congo" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria at 7 a.m. yesterday.
The S.S. "Royal Prince," from Manchester, left Malta on Thursaay and is due here on ce Monday with passengers and general embargo.
The Khedivial Mail S.S: "Prince Abbas" will on leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Piræus, at Smyrna, Mitylene and Constantinople.

div.head: GOAL FOR THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: The colliers "Yeddo" and "Calverley," flying the British flag but carrying German e super-cargoes, are still at Port Said afer a -stay of seven days. There is little doubt thathe of large cargo of coal they carry is destine for the Baltic Fleet, and it is reported that the vessels are detained by order of the Bish overnment. No actual confirmation o this an be obtained, but in view of the cent stand taken by the British Government, der 3 the Foreign Enlistment Act, with rega to coaling the Baltic Fleet at sea from British ships, it is quite probable that this is correot.

div.head: A GRIM "JOKE."
div.p: A practical joke of a particularly obnox- ous, not to say criminal, nature was perpe- rated here this morning. The many friends of Mr. Francisco Chiarini, a retired officer of the Italian Army, were shocked and amazed at receiving a funeral notice heavily eded in black which read as follows:-

quote.p: With profound sorrow we inform you of the irre parable loss of our dear friend
who died this morning at 6 45 the victim an encounter with swords against M. Emilio Herman. The funeral in civil form will take place tomorrow at 9.80, starting from the Egyptian Hospital.

div.p: The alleged victor, M. Emile Kean, is ta well-known official in the Canal Company, and both parties are swordsmen of repute. Some comment was made on the signature of the document, but as M. Chiarini has no relatives here, this passed as natural.

Excited friends of the parties soon gathered at well-known rendezvous, and many and varied reasons were assigned for the deadly encounter. Some were even heartless enough to express the at opinion that it was mean of the quellists not to have given their friends a chance It must be admit of seeing the show. ted that English opinion was just a trifle sceptical. It was hard to believe that so harm- d less a pastime as a Continental duel could have resulted in so serious an accident. Discussion al was at its height when, lo the "corpse" ap- le peared, showing every indication that a fore- noon "pick-me-up" would meet the situation far better than a sandy grave.

Seriously speaking, general indignation was expressed that any person could have been so utterly idiotic, or wilfully criminal as to have done such a thing, and enquirie are being made by the police with a view to iscovering the culprit, who it is to be hoped will, if found, be taught a severe lesson.

The Archduke Othon of Austria, who will arrive shortly in Egypt, is the nephew of the Emperor, being the son of his brother, the late Archduke Charles Louis. He was born at Gratz in 1865 and is married to the Princess Marie-Joseph of Saxony.
The son of the Emir of Bahrain, who has been paying a visit to Cairo, ha arrived at Suez en route for Jeddah.
Monsignor Aurelio Briante, the new Latin Archbishop of Egypt, will make his solemn entry into Cairo on Monday next at 3 in the afternoon.
Mr. Watmouth, of New York, as taken the steam dahabieh "Mena," which leaves for a trip up the Nile to-morrow.
Mrs. Farrar and family, who ve taken the ic dahabieh "Ammon Ra," are de at Assiout to-day.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: LA COUR D'APPEL INDIGENE
NOUVEAU PROJET DE LOI.
Monsieur le Directeur de Egyptian Gazette.

Au moment où le bruit court avec persis tance qu'on veut substituer aux tribunaux mixtes et consulaires les seuls tribunaus indigènes, le Gouvernement Egyptien, en vue sans doute de capter la confiance des puissances étrangères et du public euro péen, a commencé par bouleverser nos lois pénales et porter une main sacrilège su l'indépendance de la Cour d'Appel, seu tribunal dont les juges sont inamovibles.

Vos lecteurs me sauront peut-être gré d les mettre au courant de l'organisation judiciaire des tribunaux indigènes de ré pression et des modifications profondes qu le Gouvernement vou irait y apporter ml- gré l'opposition sourde de tous les hom- mes de loi du mode indigène.

Les habitants européens de ce pays, er effet,ne sauraient rester indifférents au bou- leversement prochain de cette organisation, ne serait-ce que pour céfendre leur propre liberté, si jamais il prend fantaisie au Gouvernement de S. A. Knédive de 1. menacer par la suppression des garantie- que différents pouvoirs tures et égyptien leur ont octroyées au cours des siècles précédents.

Lorsque le législateur égyptien voalut instituer des tribunaux modernes de ré pression,il ne erut pouvoir mieux faire qu de copier les lois pénales françaises, à l'ex ception de ce qui concerne les Cours d'as- sises et le jury. A la classification des in- fractions en crimes, délits et contraven tions correspondirent trois ordres de tri- bunaux répressifs: Un ministère public fut chargé de soutenir l'accusation, mais les mesures d'instruction devaient être con- fiées à un magistrat de l'ordre judiciaire Le tribunal réuni en chambre du conseil rappelait la chambre de mise en accusation du code français et on interjetsit devan lui appel des ordonnances du juge d'ins- truction. Pour les crimes, l'inculpé devast être assisté d'un avocat sous peine d nullité de la procédure. Pour toutes les in- fractions les crimes, n'étaient pas excep- tés-l'inculpé avait et a encore le droit de profiter de deux degrés de juridiction.Et pour complèter l'analogie avec l'organ is- tion judiciaire moderne on avait décrété l'inamovibilité des juges.

Je n'ai pas besoin de vanter devant un public européen cette organisation pour les garanties nombreuses reconnues indis- pensables par tous les législateurs moder- nes. Mais il parai, que pour notre gouver- nament elles étaient de trop; la vie d'un égyptien étant à ses yeux de beaucoup infé- rieure à celle d'un européen, il lui fallai nous arracher une à une toutes ces garanties et c'est ce qu'il ne tarda pas à faire: On commence par les juges inuamovibles de lère instance, pour lesquels on insticus un comité de surveillance; leurs jugements, actes et gestes furent rigoureusement con- trôlés. On supprima le juge d'instruction et la chambre de mise en accusation - -j voulais dire la chambre du Conseil. D judiciaire qu'elle était, l'instruction devint complètement administrative.

Besucoup de vos lecteurs qui ont eu maille à partir avec la police frémiront à la pensée que le meilleur d'entre noua pourrait être incarcéré plusieurs mois du- rant, après une courte instruction, faite par le premier adjudant venu, un ancien chaouiche, de ces chaouiches dont on célé bre tous les jours dans la presse la droiture, l'intégrité et l'esprit de sacrifice. Et su cette instruction administrative, faite par la police, l'omdeh ou un substitut quel- conque du Procureur général, le juge som- maire siégeant seul et, comme Caïn, n pouvant se soustraire jusque dans sa con- che à l'oeil qui le poursuit-l'œil du comité de surveillance judiciaire- rend une sentence nous envoyant au bagne pour trois ans,avec exécution provisoire nonobs- tant appel, pour parler le jargon du Code civil.

Jusqu'ici nous avions du moins la con- solation de nous dire que si notre liberté était menacée, on ne pouvait attenter notre vie qu'après que des conseillers ina movibles, siégeant en appel, auraient en tendu notre défense. Eh bien! cette der nière garantie, on veut nous l'arracher. L gouvernement prétend avoir le droit de nous couper la gorge en nous enlevan jusqu'au droit de crier notre innocence.
C'est l'objet du nouveau projet de loi en discussion devant le Conseil Législatif.

Tout mon être intellectuel et moral a frémi à la lecture de ce projet de loi. Le Gouvernement de la Terreur, à ses jours les plus sombres, n'a rien imaginé de pla inhumain ni de plus attentatoire à l liberté de vivre des citoyens; et, notre gou- vernement n'a même pas l'excuse d'une révolte armée menaçant son existence. Nous sommes le peuple le plus résigné qu'ait jamais enregistré l'Histoire dans Ber Bonales.

Je ne saurais mieux, faire pour montrer les atteintes multiples portées à nos droit les plus sacrés que de traduire à vos l. c- teurs le remarquable article paru dans 1 Lewa qui a été et qui est encore le sujet de toutes les conversations dans les réunions indigènes.
Ce sera, si vous le voulez bien, pour un prochain numéro.
Venillez agréer etc.

div.head: TRIBUNAL CIVIL MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: Les 7 et 14 janvier prochains étant jours fériés (Nel et premier de l'an ortho doxes), la première chambre civile ne siègera pas ce jour-là. Elle tiendra en echange une séance supplémentaire le 10 janvier.

div.head: MOUVEMENT JUDICIAIRE
div.p: La nomination de nouveaux conseillers à la Cour d'Appel indigène sera soumise prochainement à l'approbation du Conseil ies ministres, ainsi que le mouvement judiciaire projeté par le ministère de la Justice.

div.head: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
div.p: Contre le Grand Orient d'Egypte Le tribunal mixte du Caire a rendu mardi son jugement dans l'affaire Zola contre Idris Bey Ragheb, en sa qualité de représentant du Grand Orient d'Egypte. Le demandeur a été débouté de sa demande 5 et condamné à 5 P.T. d'amende pour action vexatoire.

div.head: TRIBUNAL CONSULAIRE D'ITALIE AU CAIRE
div.p: M. Capitani, qui avait tenté d'assassiner Me Morpurgo, avocat au Caire, a comparu Avant-hier devant le tribunal Consulaire d'Italie de cette ville. M. Capitani, assisté de Me Ferrugio, a déclaré ne rien se rap- peler de sa tentative d'assassinat. Me Mor- purgo ayant lui-même déclaré que M. Japitani avait subi une perturbation pro- fonde de ses facultés mentales à la suite du déraillement du 12 août 1902 à Far- shout, le tribunal, sur la demande du dé- fenseur, a renvoyé l'affaire au juge d'ins- ruction aux fius d'expertise médicale de l'accusé

div.head: Pensions des Fonctionnaires
div.p: Les fonctionnaires e employés du Gou- veruement, autorisés par le décret du 16 mat 1901 à échanger leurs pensions contre de l'argent comptant, pourront présenter eurs demandes au Ministère des Finances. Ceux d'entre eux qui auraient déja échan- gé la moitié de leur pension en 1901 ou en 1902 sont exclus de la présente invita- tion; aucune suite ne sera donnée à leurs Jemandes.

Voici les dispositions du décret du 16 mai 1901: Art. I. Le ministre des Fi- nances est autorisé à racheter, contre de l'argent comptant, les pensions des fone- Gionnaires es employés, reversibles après décès ou payables jusqu'au décès seulement Art II. Les pensions de L.E. 10 par mois et au-dessous, seront rachetées pou. leur monta at intégral; les pensions supe- rieures à LE. 10 par mois, pour la moi.ie de leur montant seulement.

Ac III. Le rach st n'est obligatoire ui pour le gouvernement ni pour les peu- sionnaires; lorsqu il est effectué, il éteint tous droits tant des pensionnaires eux-mê- mes que de leurs héritiers ou ayants droit à la pension ou à la partie de la pension ayant fait l'objet du rachat. En consé- quence, la partie non racheté de la pen- sion seca seule, le cas échéant, réversible dans les conditions et limites déterminées par les lois en vigueur.
Art. IV. Le rachat sera effectué après constatation de l'âge du pensionnaire.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Aujourd'hus à midi et demi

L'ouverture de ce matin a été déplorable par suite des nouvelles du marché de Lo.- dres et des manoeuvres des baissiers. Peu à peu, cependant, sur de forts achats, les cours ont sensiblement repris pour fléchir de nouveau en clôture.

Voici un aperçu des valeurs les plus mouvementées: On a fait 1000 à 1500 Banque Nationale à un prix variant de 21 3/8 à 21 1/2, 1000 Agricole entre 10 3/8 et 10 7/16, 5 à 6000 Salt & Sod entre 37 I et 38/1, 2000 Banque d'Athènes entre 119 et 117.

Les prix de clôture montrent que la baisse s'accentue. La Banque Nationale tombe à 21 7/16, l'Agricole à 9 7/16, la Bébéra à 50 (en baisse de 2 Livres), la Delta Land à 8 1/4, la Wardan à 7 1/2, Is Daïra à 20 7/8, in Salt & Soda à 37/3, 14 Banque d'Athènes à 118 1/2, la Nangovich à 8 3/8, les Eaux d'Alexandrie à 15 7/8, la Delta Light à 14 3/16.
La Filature se maintient à 13/16 et ler Cotton Milts remontent à 7- acheteurs et l'Anglo American Nile à 4 5/16.
Comme les positions resteront surcher- gées jusqu'à la fin du mois, on prévoit que la prochaine liquidation sera également très laborieuse.

div.head: The Question of Nationality
div.p: To the Members of the British Colony Fentlemen,

About two years ago H. M.'s Government instituted a Commission, composed of the Law Officers, of the Crown, and Under Secretaries of State, assisted by the highest legal Commsel in the United Kingdom, for the purpose of drawing up a new and general law of nationality to govern the status of all British subjects resident in foreign countries.

Having been informed that the projected new law had been drawn up,and it being hinted to us that it affected British subjects in the Levant also, we applied for a copy and to our consternation found that the Turkish dominions and Egypt were expressly included under its scope and that British subjects of the third generation born therein would under its clauses rease to be recognised as such. At the same time we received private warnings from well- placed and well disposed British official friends. that unless immediate measures were taken the new project would be established by Act of Parliament and become the law of the land, in which case it would be difficult, if not quite impossible, to reverse it.

After consultation with competent persons the following considerations presented them- selves as indispensable conditions of any snc- cessful attempt to exempt the Turkish Do- minions from the provisions of the new law.

1st. That decided steps should be taken immediately in London firmly, but very quietly. and without publicity so as to avoid wounding the susceptibilities or stirring up amour propre and, most probably, the opposition of the eminent and influential men who had drawn up the new law.

2nd. That it was desirable to avoid attracting the attention of the Turkish Government. to the peculiar position which would be created t voluntarily by H. M.'s Government under the h new law for British subjects in the Turkish dominions, Egypt, etc.

Acting on these urgent considerations, and in view of the very serious interests at stake to t our British communities in the Levant and Egypt, we took the initiative and the responsi bility of following the only course that occurred to us, viz., to consult Mr. E. Pears, the best living authority on all questions affecting the Capitulations, of which he had made a special study, and on the status of foreign subjects in Turkey, and to request him to proceed to London at once and there to plead our canse Mr. Pears recognised the gravity of the situa- tion and agreed to go to London and to do his best for the moderate sum of £200. In Lon- don Mr. Pears ascertained that the position was even more critical than our official friends here had led us to believe. He forthwith set about interviewing the Law officers of the Crown, the officials of the Foreign Office, but though w their expert advisers, etc., his legal and other arguments were respectfully listened to and the force of many of them admitted, the only immediate result he could obtain was a sort of promise to suspend the actual enactment of the law for further consideration of his claims. Mr. Pears then returned to Constantinople. Some months later, there being no improvement in the position, we asked Mr. Pears to go to London for a second time and agreed to pay him £100 further for his expenses. Mr. Pears went and had again the same ordeals to go through, but in this case was requested to draw up a statement of the whole case in extenso. This statement, for which Mr. Pears was quite prepared, proyed a long and extraordinarily lucid and convincing document, treating the whole question ever since the institution of the Capitulations over 400 years age, bringing out the intention of same, and the unbroken usage during this long period, and referring to many judgments and legal opinions affecting the subject.

This learned exposé of the case appears to have had some effect on the experts in London, but still no favorable solution was reached till Mr. Pears, having to go to London on other business, stirred up the matter a third time.

We are now happy to inform you that a communication from H.M.'s Ambassador has reached us to the effect that H.M.'s Govern- ment has finally resolved to adopt the views. pressed on it by Mr. Pears and to recognise the full British status of all descendants of British subjects of whatever generation, born in the Turkish Dominions.

The question now arises as to the payment. of the £300 promised to Mr. Pears, which we have no need to say forms scarcely any remu- neration at all for his trouble and expenses, and for his eminent and important services.

We appeal to our fellow British subjects in Turkey and Egypt for subscriptions to cover thium spent so successfully in saving them or their future descendants from becoming Rayahs or Turkish subjects.
We beg all intending subscribers to notify and end in their subscriptions to:
Messrs.
J. W. WHITTALL & Co. Constantinople.
C. B. CHARNAUD ESQ. Régie des Tabacs, Constantinople.
C. WHITTALL & Co. PATERSON & Co. Smyrna.
Signed
J. WILLIAM WHITTALL, Salonica.
C. B. CHARNAUD, Beyrout.
SYDNEY M. FONTAINE, Alexandria.

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND,
div.p: The following appeal is being issued by the Egypt Exploration Fund:--

The Committee of the Egypt Exploration Fund have had under careful consideration 1. present condition of the finances of the Fund and of its branches, the Archeolo gical Survey and the Graco-Roman branch. I ach of these there has been a decline of income daring the past year, but more especially in the case of the Fund proper. In the United Kingdom the subscriptions have been well maintained, but those received from the United States of America show a very serious diminution. This is due to two principal causes, the withdrawal of the support of the affiliated branches of Chicago, Philadelphia, and New York, and the reduc tion in the receipts from the head office at Boston. For several years past the income from the affiliated branches amounted in all to about £400, nearly the whole of which was available for the purposes of the expeditions to Egypt. The withdrawal of these branches and the falling off in the remittances from Boston have reduced the income derived from America to one-third of what was formerly received. It is to be feared that unless it is possible to augment the number of subscribers in the United Kingdom, or to obtain an increased individual subscription, the work of the Fund. in Egypt will have to be brought within narrower limits.

During the coming season it is proposed tha Prof. Petrie, who is the permanent officer of the Fund in charge of excavations, shall go to Sinai, where he hopes to collect important data relating to the early history of Egypt. In Egypt itself, M. Naville, with the assistance of Mr. H. R. Hall, will continue at Deir el- Bahari the clearing of the site of the earlier terrace-temple, adjacent to that of Queen Hatshepsu, which they discovered last winter. This work, which was commenced last season, is scarcely half achieved, and must be brought. to a proper conclusion. Funds, therefore, have in some way to be found to carry it out. It is a site of very great promise, both historic- ally and archæologically; and, moreover, the Fund is under an engagement with the Egyp tian authorities not to abandon it till its clearance has been effected.

In his report to the general meeting of the Fund held on November 11th, the hon. trea- surer showed that after deducting the expenses (including salaries and authorship) of the publications annually distributed to each subscriber to the Fund, and after allowing for office expenses, the ordinary subscription of one guinea leaves only the small margin of 3s. to be devoted to labor and other outlay on excavations. This margin is too small for practical purposes, and it is evident that the chief cost of the excavations has hitherto been borne by those whose annual contributions are in excess of one guinea.

In order, therefore, to meet the expenses of the coming season's work, the Committee would appeal to the subscribers of one guinea or under, and would suggest that, if possi ble, they should generously double their subscription for at least the current year, or make some substantial donation to the Fund. If this appeal should meet with a general response there will be no difficulty in providing sufficient means for the excava tions of the coming season. Failing this, it is feared that the Fund will have to draw upon its small capital, which would be a cause for much regret.

What has been said about the Fund and the minimum subscription applies also to the Archaeological Survey and to the Grieco- Roman branch, but it has been felt by these in a somewhat less degree, as the excava tions connected with these branches do not cost so much as those of the Fund. There has, however, been for some time past a di- minution in these cases likewise in the ba-I lance of the previous year; and the Com- mittee therefore ask their supporters for an increased subscription, and also for assistancé in enlisting new members, as it is most desi- rable that the financial position of the bran- ches should be improved in order to carry on effectively the work in which they are engaged.

div.head: "WHO'S WHO YEAR BOOK.
div.p: This is a unique tabular array of useful information purveyed in the handiest form. It is made up of the tables which were formerly such a popular feature in Who's Who itself. These tables were, in fact, the original nucleus of the book, which developed on different lines into a biographical annual. Thus, though the two books are now entirely. distinct, there is an underlying connection, and additional details concerning all persons of eminence who are entered in the tables of the Year-Book will be found in Who's Who. In spite of the large number of reference books there is still need for such a work, where the information can be seen literally at a glance, and which includes not only the gist of in- formation contained in many expensive pub- lications, but some original tables to be found nowhere else.

div.head: ENGLISHWOMAN'S YEAR BOOK.
div.p: This is the seventh year of the new issue of the "Englishwoman's Year Book and Directory" and this work has been revised, enlarged and entirely remodelled. It is a book which every Englishwoman in Egypt, who takes an interest in the development of her sex, should possess, for it gives a wonderful insight into the achievements of women at home.
Who's Who Year Book London: Adam and Charles Black, 8oho-rquare, In. net,
The Englishwoman's Year Book and Directory 1906. Edited by Emily Janes. London: Adam and Charles Black. 2s. 6d. net.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: A correspondent writes as follows to the Globe Acut Egypt possessed a large and m prosperous goldfield; had an output of gold n almost as a, preciable as that now won on the e Rand. The names of the places where the gold was won are lost; the very districts remain unknown. Whether the gold was richer in Egypt than the Sudan, or vice versa, is to- e day impossible of proof. The country is now being explored, and time will show. Very little s is known to the world (outside a few small d mining groups directed by such conservative and experienced engineers as John Taylor and, o Sons and Mr. Alford) about the minerals of e Egypt. The first gold mine, that discovered in 1899 by Mr ord, is about to begin crushing, and it the s expectations public interest at may be w. Loned. Another called Nile Valley e has been lucky enough to strike a rich pocket, out of which a good many thousands of pounds' hworth have been taken. It is also erecting the necessary machinery for treating the quartz se in a business manner. John Taylor and Sons haye in the Sudan a third mine, of which great e hopes are entertained. In addition to these at three admitted mines, as distinguished from" at mere prospects, there are numberless ancient er workings which are now known to have once or been gold mines upon which large numbers of workmen are employed in sinking shafts, driv- eing levels, and clearing away the débris of of CO centuries

The capital con-- r.sists of 60,000 shares of £1 each, of which 1,40,000 are to be allotted to the vendors as tfully paid up in payment of the purchase , consideration of £40,000, leaving 20,000 shares for the provision of working capital.

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL.
div.p: Signor Saporito, President of the Royal n Commission on the Italian Railways, has just 1. presented his report to the Ministry of Public Works. The report contains one paragraph of special interest to Egyptian readers, viz., that which deals with the weekly P. and O. express train to Brindisi.

I pointed out last summer, from consider alable personal experience of the Adriatic route, the many deficiencies which are allowed to e delay the transit of that train. Signor Saporito sfully confirms all that I then wrote, and he e quotes eloquent figures which show that the number of passengers travelling annually between London and Brindisi, and vice versa, has fallen off from two thousand eight hundred in 1903 to one thousand five hundred and fifty s last year. Such a result was only to be expected.

So long as the line from Bologna to Brindisi 8 remains single, delays are bound to occur, while the company complains that the rolling-stock used for the weekly express is unsuited to the exigencies of the railway. Moreover, the fares are very high-a fact of importance when it is remembered that a large proportion of Anglo- Indian travellers, officers and civilians, are not millionaires.

Signor Saporito's report suggests that "some- thing should be done," and that in compensa tion for the increased expense which it should be asked to bear the Adriatic Company ought to have an extra allowance from the Govern- ment. Sooner or later, no doubt, the Brindisi route will cease to be used, when the Vienna- R Nish-Salonika or Vienna-Larissa-Piræus lines ne (the last named as yet in an embyro condition) displaces it. Such a change will mean the ruin d of Brindisi, the port of departure for the East since the days of Horace and Virgil. But th two poets, fortunately for them, did not trave by the Adriatic Railway, but by the scarcely slower route of the Appian Road

The first weekly golf competition takes place on Friday'next, and there seems every pro bability of a good entry, the links being in excellent order, thanks to the energetic efforts. zof Fulford, the professional.

The Royal Engineers,, who have been in camp, close to the race-course, the last three weeks, under the command of Major Bigge, hold their sports on Saturday afternoon next. Numerous invitations have been issued by Col. Friend and officers of the corps. This annual event, is conjunction with the beautiful weather now prevailing at Helouan, should fensure an enjoyable afternoon.
The chaplain for this season to the English church, the Rev. A. H. Longley, recently arrived and has taken up his residence at the Grand Hotel.
Mrs. Barker has once again shown her great tinterest in the church by generously presenting some curtains for the chancel.
It is pleasant to welcome back Dr. and Mrs. Page May on a visit of a few weeks' duration to Dr. Overton Hobson at Villa Sakkara.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.p: N.B. – Ne seront admis dans les deux trains No 3 et 24, que les voyageurs porteurs de billets de 1re et 2e classe seulement et les abonnés à ces deux classes. N.B. Tous les mardis et les jeudis de chaque semaine, pendant la saison théâtrale à l'Opéra Khédivial le dernier train partira de Bab-el-Louk à 12h.45 au lieu de 12h.30.
